ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Amazing opportunity, learned an incredible amount -- thank you!
The readings weren't particularly helpful or dealt with or discussed. It may be more helpful to have shorter readings that are directly applicable.

Jodi also should be giving credit. She was super responsive and helpful too. Dr. Leaderer was great and quick to respond.I love the air quality monitor experiment. That was interesting - and the write up was appropriate to the work (i.e., not something overly complex).I like the outside assignments (take home midterm and paper). They are helpful to really learn the material - not just the memorize and purge method of test taking. At least for me it helps me retain the knowledge better.

Thought course would have been better if there were more clinical project meetings with profs and fewer"introduction to environmental law and environmental studies" courses. The info in those classes was well presented but basic.

I thought the course was very helpful in learning about the legal aspects of environmental policy and legislation. The ability to work with a client on a project was definitely the most rewarding part of the experience. Although our project had a slow start, in the end I believe we all learned a lot about the issue and were able to create final products that can help our client.The moot court and climate change negotiations were the two most fun experiences in the class, and also the most educational.

This course is one of the best at F&ES because it gives the opportunity to work with a client, os at the same time you do research you lean how to work with different stakeholders and earn experience.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Application based!
The lectures and interacting with the instructors.
Air quality practice. Speakers. Reviewing journal articles.

Producing a useful product for the client. Building a relationship with the client. Being creative withlegal mechanisms and learning how to interpret legal documents. I felt I gained new skills and new knowledge and I liked how applied it was.
Working with the client and learning how to run a project.
Having real-world experiences in a new area of interest to build up my expertise and communicate actual problem-solving skills to potential employers.

The fact that each team was assigned a client and a specific project. I really enjoyed the interaction with our client, Islands First, and the possibility to participate in the UNFCCC intercessional meeting.
The client based project is a great experience and resume builder.
Working with clinic supervisors and the moot court.
The firsthand experience with a legal environmental issue
Wide variety of project options.
The opportunity to work with a client and apply one's learning to a project with real-world significance.
The team project was a great experience. The professors were great, every class was super interesting. I enjoyed this class very much.
Working on a project with a client that will have impacts outside of the academic environment.
The autonomy for students to craft a professional deliverable andwork with the client to scope and hone the project over the semester is invaluable experience.
Case studies, and working with clients.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Mid-semester reports from classmates would be interesting

The projects are interesting but possibly too intensive. The point of this class I thought was to bridge law and environmental management/science, but it seemed like there was little science and not all teams had both a law student and an forestry student. It seems like the course would benefit from someone who is not a lawyer to assist in bridging the gap between the two worlds (schools).
can't think of any

While I really enjoyed the project work for the client, I think the classes could do with some improvement. I was excited about taking the classes at the beginning of the semester because they all covered interesting and important topics. But there needed to be more of a seminar-style discussion, particularly after we had done the reading - we didn't need a rehash of what the reading said in the form of a 2-hour lecture. Some of the topics e.g. cost-benefit analysis are controversial so it would have been interesting and fun to discuss them, but instead the classes were more like lectures.
The classroom part of the course had nothing to do with our projects. They were interesting, but it was frustrating that all the extra work did not count towards my project time.
Work with clients to make sure the preparatory legwork is as complete as possible before the semester begins.
More connection between classes and projects assigned.

While I enjoyed the mock trial and climate negotiation simulation, the other in class components of this course did not present much new material to me. I would have appreciated more law/legal material rather than environmental material.
Make lectures on environmental economics, environmental law, and energy more advanced and less introductory. Too basic for most, since the course was mostly FES, anyway.

I think some of the course material could be improved to be more engaging and accessible to FES students without legal background. Some of the information was very basic, almost too basic, while other information was more challenging to grasp.I think a second moot court could have been a fun way for us to improve upon the feedback we received after the first moot court.
This class is well-designed, well-ran and efficiently administered. No suggested improvements. That said, you will have a hard time finding a TA as excellent as Hayley!
Being able to couple readings with research being done by students.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very effective
It was fine.
effectively done
n/a
There was a bit of a disconnect between the lectures and the moot court and projects.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Interest in application based coursework
It seems important to understand all sides of environmental law.
fits into my interest
The project I was assigned to did not actually fit with my overall coursework, but it was great to add another type of focus to my work.
I focus mostly on economics, so this course was a departure from my normal program. However, I learned a lot about applying economics to real world issues and the challenges this presents.
This course is very relevant to my academic background as a dual-degree law and Master of Environmental Management candidate.
The project allowed me to work in further understanding the topics that I was learning in other classes related to energy policy and renewable energy.
It fits well into my background as someone with nearly a decade of environmental policy experience.
It is a great class to gain experience and to be able to network with clients for future internships, jobs, and consulting experiences.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest in the projects
To bridge the area between environment and law.
it sounded interesting.
To gain experience of working with an external organisation, to develop my knowledge of environmental law and policy, to work in a team. The syllabus looked interesting.
To implement my skills and knowledge for a practical purpose, and to gain experience doing such a project.
One of the few opportunities that we have to gain real world experience and skills.
Because of the possiblity to work on something related to Climate Change with a real practical project.
It served as a practical experience and a capstone as well.
Professional Experience
To gain experience working with a client on a real-world project.
Because of the chance to do a clinic and take class at the same time.
I wanted the exposure given by working with a client.
Because of the autonomy and ability to work on interesting projects.
Because I was recommended to have an experience of having a client.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: YES!
Yes.
I would have liked to learn a little more about the relation between the science of health impacts and policy.

More or less, though the classes would have been more helpful if there had been more discussion. I thought the Moot Court was great, the climate negotiation simulation slightly less great but still interesting.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, it exceeded them
Yes. I have built up my resume as well.
Exceeded!
Yes, but experience with project supervisor was less than optimal.
Yes
Exceeded.
Yes!
Yes
Yes
Yes. I learned a lot both semesters and valued the ability to research, write, and author a report with no prior knowledge on the subject.
Yes, they over-exceeded by expectations by far.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Collaboration, innovation
NA
I had an awesome group, we organised ourselves well from the beginning and worked well together, so I got a lot out of it.

It helped to share the responsibility, and to bounce ideas off each other. I think it formed a better product. At the same time, having other people involved means that coordination takes a larger part of your time, and you always have to consider the possibility that they won't come through.
While I worked in a group, we mostly worked separately. So I'd say being able to tackle a bigger project more substantially than would have been possible if we were each working on our own projects.
The group work was great. We had a very good team work dynamic.
It was difficult to coordinate schedules for internal deadlines sometimes.
We were one of the larger groups which meant that we could dig much deeper into our project's issues than some other groups.The disadvantage was a slight tendency to become siloed within our group.

The group work was a great way to learn about the perspectives of students from other disciplines. However, I think it was challenging at first for us to grasp our specific roles in the project and find a way to make each person's efforts cohesive and build on the efforts of the others.
Students assigned to projects based on interest and background -made groups dynamic and effective.

I had a particularly excellent and positive group experience. Everyone was very collaborative, hard working, thorough, and great with communication. The only challenge was coordinating busy schedules for meetings.
It is difficult sometimes to coordinate times with your team mates. You have to start very early in the semester so that at the end you are not stressing over remaining hours.
N/A

Advantages: covering more material than I would have been able to on my own.Disadvantages: working with a friend and changing a proven formula (team membership) ended up backfiring. Our team would have benefitted from losing our previous 3rd member and leaving the team as a two-person team instead of adding a third member that did not end up meeting the expectations that the previous iterationof the group had set.

Advantages: having a very rich conversation and learning from them.Disadvantages: if the team is not working the same amount of hours simultaneously, some members can delay on their final deliverables.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Enjoy!
Get on a good team and try tokeep up with your hours.

Get organised right from the start, make a good work plan with your team and stick to it, work on building a good relationship with the client and make sure communications are clear. Try to spread the workload through the semester so it doesn't build up at the end.
Budget the time, and work consistently and early.

I highly recommend it. All FESers should take this course. if there is a project that even semi-fits your interests, it's a great way to make connections with NGO's and other groups and put real world experience on your resume.
Dive into your project early!
Ask questions of your project sponsor early. If any red lights go off, ask to switch projects. Start hours early. Be sure of what everyone else's expectations are.
The EPC is an incredible opportunity as long as the group and supervisor are as invested in the project as you. Thus, be careful to review and choose the project carefully.
Take it! It's a great course, consider its a big time commitment though.
It is a great opportunity to work in projects different from the ones in lecture based courses.
Choose your project and, mort importantly, your teammates wisely.
Great course, great instructors, and take it on your first year so you can take it or follow up with clients on your second year.
